issuetype.description: A problem which impairs or prevents the functions of the product.
issuetype.name: Bug

resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.
status.name: Closed

fields.description:
When tried to create a security group with the name,

abc`~!@#$%^&*()_+0-+{}[]|\:;<>?><,.

, the create security group page was able to create the group, however when displayed on the landing page, it showed the error message below:

The security group 'abc`~!@#$%^&*()_+0-+{}[]|\:;<>?><,.' does not exist

It was created without any rules. When tried to add rules, it results in the same error as above.

See the attachment.
fields.summary: Able to create a security group with the name abc`~!@#$%^&*()_+0-+{}[]|\:;<>?><,.

comments.body: When trying to delete the group, it fails and displays the same error as above.
Having the group above broke the instance launch wizard and the launch config wizard. Even worse, the UI cannot delete the group due to the error above.
Also able to create a keypair with the same name, and again, the UI cannot delete the keypair once created.
could have upgrade ramifications for those using sg's with this character set
This also will have impacts on EC2 service

The problem was the use of "\" (backward-slash) char.

When the name was selected to be "\", it failed to create a new security group and returned the error message shown in the new attachment.

When the name "\1" was used, it created the security group, failed to add rules, and broke the instance and launch wizard.

Here is an example of security group best practices - http://walkintocloud.com/2014/01/amazon-aws-ec2-best-practices-part-1/.

Notice what was mentioned in step 1:

*Security Groups & Key Pairs Management* 

* Follow the Standard Naming convention to the  Key Pairs and Security Groups Example: WordPress_Prod_App_SG & Wordpess_Prod_App_Key

This is one example, and I am sure there are others.  Just wanted to provide a use case example that users *may* refer to when they try to use the same best practices mentioned for security groups on AWS with Eucalyptus.

Here is another use case where this product Clustrix discusses security group management with ELB - http://docs.clustrix.com/display/CLXDOC/Configure+EC2+Elastic+Load+Balancer+for+ClustrixDB+AWS

{quote}
Once you have created the Elastic Load Balancer, you need to add the ELB Source Security Group to the Security Groups tied to your ClustrixDB EC2 instances.
....
You can find the ELB Source Security Group by selecting your Load Balancer from the Management Console and selecting the Description tab. In this example, the ELB Source Security Group is _amazon-elb/amazon-elb-sg_. This also a place to record the ELS DNS Name since, in order to use the ELB, all traffic will need to be routed to the DNS Name.
{quote}

Again here - this just sheds light as to what users could *potentially* do with Eucalyptus security groups.

[~hspencer] Awesome. Thank you for the link! Will definitely try to test cases based on the best practices. The current focus, as seen from this ticket, is to find any strange corner cases for the keypair and security group names that might result in cascading effects on other parts of UI since we are dealing with possibly the worse case of the keypair and security names' restrictions being "Constraints for EC2-Classic: ASCII characters" :)

[~kgill] [~jloza] I saw that this ticket has been pushed to 4.0.1.

To raise the severity of this issue, I'm still not able to delete the keypair with the name "abc`~!@#$%^&*()_+0-+{}[]|\:;<>?><,." neither with the eucaconsole nor euca2ools. So, the account "ui-test-acct-00" which contains the keypair above is completely disabled from launching any new instances.
[~kyolee]: If we can't delete the security group via the console or euca2ools, we should open a EUCA ticket to address this.
[~kgill] Security group can be delete since it uses the ID to delete, but we cannot delete the keypair neither with eucaconsole and euca2ools. Will file a ticket.

[~kgill] euca2ools ticket regarding the issue above is created here:

https://eucalyptus.atlassian.net/browse/TOOLS-465
The primary issue here is the backslash
fix for 4.0.1 would be to update validation rules here to not allow / or \
